title: Ticket #3923: OpenNebula doesn't like long EC2 user data
description: HTCondor can't successfully submit jobs to OpenNebula when the job supplies user data of more than ~2K. Comparison with the functioning euca-tools revealed that HTCondor was embedding newlines in the base64 encoding of the user data in the URI. It's not clear why this might be a size-dependent problem, but testing w/o the embedded newlines and 3.6KB of user data succeeded.
remarks:
2013-Sep-16 16:47:05 by tlmiller:
The obvious approach -- asking OpenSSL to not emit newlines -- failed because it (somehow) broke signature generation. Instead, the code removes newlines from the base64-encoded user data string (before URL-encoding).

2013-Sep-16 17:03:29 by tlmiller: 

  diff --git a/src/ec2_gahp/amazonCommands.cpp b/src/ec2_gahp/amazonCommands.cpp
  index 74c1362..0d13970 100644
  --- a/src/ec2_gahp/amazonCommands.cpp
  +++ b/src/ec2_gahp/amazonCommands.cpp
  @@ -714,6 +714,7 @@ bool AmazonVMStart::workerFunction(char **argv, int argc, std::string &result_st


     //
     // Handle user data.
+    // (FIXME: Will this code have problems with embedded NULs?)
     //
     std::string buffer;
     if( strcasecmp( argv[7], NULLSTRING ) ) {
  @@ -730,7 +731,21 @@ bool AmazonVMStart::workerFunction(char **argv, int argc, std::string &result_st
         buffer += udFileContents;
     }
     if( ! buffer.empty() ) {
         char * base64Encoded = condor_base64_encode( (const unsigned char *)buffer.c_str(), buffer.length() );
+
+        // OpenNebula barfs on embedded newlines in this data.
+        char * read = base64Encoded;
+        char * write = base64Encoded;
+        for( ; * read != '\0'; ++read ) {
+            char tmp = * read;
+            if( tmp != '\n' ) {
+                * write = tmp;
+                ++write;
+            }
+        }
+        * write = '\0';
+
         vmStartRequest.query_parameters[ "UserData" ] = base64Encoded;
         free( base64Encoded );
     }

2013-Sep-17 13:32:55 by jfrey:
CODE REVIEW

This code change looks good. Embedded NULs shouldn't be a problem for this new code, as they should be encoded after condor_base64_encode(). However, readShortFile() does have an issue with embedded NULs. That should be fixed, but that's a separate ticket.
